item.label: Cerebral gyri, Insula
item.name: Insular cortex
item.description: The insula is an area of cerebral cortex (AKA insular cortex or Island of Reil) that is concealed by the opercula of the frontal, parietal and temporal gyri. It was originally the lateral surface of the telencephalon but was overgrown during development by the other cerebral lobes. It generally consists of three short gyri located anteriorly and two long gyri located posteriorly.

item.label: Cerebral gyri, Parahippocampal
item.name: Parahippocampal gyrus
item.description: The parahippocampal gyrus is the most medial gyrus on the ventral aspect of the temporal lobe. The hippocampus is cortex that is rolled up inside the parahippocampal gyrus. The rostral portion of this gyrus is the entorhinal cortex.

item.label: Cerebral fissure, Lateral
item.name: Lateral fissure
item.description: The lateral fissure or sulcus is AKA the Sylvian fissure. It is a long, deep sulcus on the lateral aspect of each cerebral hemisphere that separates the frontal and parietal lobes from the temporal lobe.  The main portion of the fissure is sometimes referred to as the posterior ramus.  Anteriorly, the fissure branches to subdivide the inferior frontal gyrus; anterior horizontal and anterior ascending rami delineate the orbital, triangular and opercular portions of the inferior frontal gyrus.  The cortex known as the insula is located deep within this sulcus and the transverse temporal gyri (auditory cortex) is located on the temporal lobe aspect of the fissure.

item.label: Lamina terminalis
item.name: Lamina terminalis
item.description: The lamina terminalis is a thin membrane at the rostral end of the third ventricle that represents the original rostral extent of the developing telencephalon. It extends from near the rostrum of the corpus callosum down to the optic chiasm and passes immediately anterior to the anterior commissure.

item.label: Anterior perforated substance
item.name: Ant perforated substance
item.description: The anterior perforated substance is located on the inferior surface of the forebrain between the orbital gyri and the optic chiasm. Numerous small blood vessels branching from the anterior and middle cerebral arteries (lenticulostriate) penetrate this area to supply adjacent brain structures. These penetrating vessels are the source of the perforated appearance.

item.label: Hippocampal formation
item.name: Hippocampal formation
item.description: The hippocampus is AKA the hippocampal formation. It is an area of cerebral cortex rolled up inside the medial aspect of the temporal lobe. It is part of the limbic system and functions in the consolidation of new memories of facts and events. It has three subdivisions: the hippocampus proper (Ammon's horn), the dentate gyrus, and the subiculum. The fornix carries the primary output from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal area and hypothalamus.

item.label: Alveus
item.name: Alveus
item.description: The alveus of the hippocampus is a thin sheet of nerve fibers located on the ventricular surface of the hippocampus. Cell bodies of origin are pyramidal neurons in the hippocampus; these nerve fibers aggregate to form the fimbria prior to entering the fornix.

item.label: Fornix
item.name: Fornix
item.description: The fornix is a compact bundle of axons, primarily efferents from the hippocampus to the ipsilateral septal nuclei and hypothalamus. Parts of the fornix from the hippocampus and beyond are the fimbria, crus, body and column.

item.label: Fimbriae
item.name: Fimbriae
item.description: The fimbria is a band of white matter along the medial edge of the hippocampus.  It consists of the myelinated axons that formed the alveus on the ventricular surface of the hippocampus.  Near the splenium of the corpus callosum, the fimbria separate from the hippocampus and become the crus of the fornix.

item.label: Columns
item.name: Columns
item.description: The columns of the fornix is the portion that leaves the body of the fornix to turn ventrally and then caudally toward the septal nuclei and mammillary bodies of the hypothalamus.

item.label: Caudate nucleus
item.name: Caudate nucleus
item.description: The caudate nucleus is the medial portion of the striatum. It consists of a large head that bulges into the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle, a body that narrows and curves along the body of the lateral ventricle and a tail that continues through the atrium or trigone of the lateral ventricle and into the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. Principal connections are with the prefrontal and other association areas of cerebral cortex.

item.label: Head
item.name: Head
item.description: The head of the caudate nucleus is the largest portion of the caudate.  It bulges into the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle. It is located medial to the anterior limb of the internal capsule.

item.label: Tail
item.name: Tail
item.description: The tail of the caudate nucleus is the long, slender portion that runs posteriorly from the body of the caudate toward the atrium or trigone of the lateral ventricle and then continues into the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle.

item.label: Putamen
item.name: Putamen
item.description: The putamen is the large lateral component of the lentiform nucleus, located lateral to the globus pallidus and the internal capsule. With the caudate nucleus, it is known as the striatum. Portion of the striatum most involved in the motor function of the basal ganglia. Receives afferents from motor and somatosensory cerebral cortex, substantia nigra and centromedian nucleus of the thalamus; sents efferents to globus pallidus.

item.label: Thalamus, Lateral geniculate nucl.
item.name: Lateral geniculate
item.description: The lateral geniculate thalamic nucleus (LGN) deals with vision.  It receives input from the retina via the optic nerve and tract. It projects to the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe (cuneus and lingual gyri) via the geniculocalcarine tract.  The geniculocalcarine tract is AKA the optic radiation and travels in both the sublenticular and retrolentricular portions of the internal capsule.

item.label: Thalamus, Medial geniculate nucl.
item.name: Medial geniculate
item.description: The medial geniculate thalamic nucleus (MGN) deals with hearing.  It receives input from the cochlea via the cochlear nuclei, lateral lemniscus and inferior colliculus. It projects to primary auditory cortex in the temporal lobe (transverse temporal or Heschl's gyri) via the sublenticular part of the internal capsule.

item.label: Mammillothalamic tract
item.name: Mamillothalamic tract
item.description: The mammillothalamic tract is a bundle of fibers projecting from the mammillary body to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. It is part of the Papez circuitry of the limbic system.

item.label: Visual pathway, Optic radiation
item.name: Optic radiations
item.description: The Optic Radiation is AKA geniculocalcarine tract. It is a massive bundle of myelinated nerve fibers that originate in the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus and terminate in the upper and lower banks of the calcarine sulcus in the occipital lobe. It travels through the sublenticular and retrolenticular portions of the posterior limb of the internal capsule.

item.label: Midbrain, Tectum, Superior colliculus
item.name: Superior colliculus
item.description: The superior colliculi are paired, rounded structures on the superior surface of the rostral midbrain formed by the laminated or layered nuclei of the superior colliculi. Along with the paired inferior colliculi in the caudal midbrain, they form the tectum or roof of the midbrain and are collectively referred to as the corpora quadrigemina. The superior colliculus receives input from the retina and visual cortex and sends its output to the pulvinar of the thalamus, and plays a role in controlling eye movements, etc..

item.label: Midbrain, Tegmentum, Red nucleus
item.name: Red nucleus
item.description: The red nucleus is a large, round nucleus in the tegmentum of the midbrain that appears pink or red on freshly-sectioned tissue. It is involved with motor control via its connections with the cerebellum. It receives contralateral input from both the dentate and interposed deep cerebellar nuclei; its primary output in the human is to the ipsilateral inferior olivary nucleus via the central tegmental tract. Since the inferior olivary nucleus projects to contralateral cerebellum, the red nucleus is part of a feedback loop to the cerebellum. While the red nucleus gives origin to a significant rubrospinal tract in non-human species, this tract appears to be of limited extent and importance in humans.

item.label: Midbrain, Substantia nigra
item.name: Substantia nigra
item.description: The substantia nigra is a large band-like nucleus in the midbrain located between the crus cerebri and the red nuclei of the tegmentum. It has two parts: 1) a compact portion consisting of closely packed dopaminergic neurons filled with neuromelanin pigment. These neurons project to the striatum & are the ones damaged in Parkinson disease; 2) a reticular portion consisting of loosely packed neurons that receive input from the striatum and project to the thalamus.

item.label: Midbrain, Cerebral crus
item.name: Int capsule (post limb)
item.description: The cerebral crus is AKA the crus cerebri or the basis pedunculi. This most ventral or inferior aspect of the paired cerebral peduncles contains motor axons originating primarily in the cerebral cortex. The bulk of the cerebral crus is made up of the corticospinal, corticobulbar and corticopontine tract fibers that have left the cerebral cortex, traveled through the internal capsule and will terminate in the spinal cord and brain stem.

item.label: Cerebellum
item.name: Cerbellum
item.description: The cerebellum is sometimes referred to as the 'small' brain.  It is located within the posterior fossa, superior to the brain stem. It consists of a finely convoluted cortical surface of folia, a central core of white matter (AKA medullary center) and four paired deep nuclei (dentate, emboliform, fastigial and globose) embedded within the white matter core. The cerebellum functions in the planning and coordination of movement.

item.label: Anterior cerebral artery
item.name: Ant cerebral a
item.description: The anterior cerebral artery is the most anterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it curves around the genu and then superior to the corpus callosum to supply the orbital gyri, medial aspect of the frontal lobe, a portion of the parietal lobe and a narrow band along the most superior region of the lateral aspect of the hemisphere. Since the anterior cerebral artery supplies the paracentral lobule which is responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral lower extremity, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower extremity.

item.label: Middle cerebral a. branches
item.name: Mid cerebral a. branches
item.description: The middle cerebral artery is the most posterior of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. Along with its branches, it travels through the lateral sulcus to supply the insula, the lateral aspect of the frontal and parietal lobes and the anterior tip of the temporal lobe. Since the middle cerebral artery supplies the pre- and post-central gyri which are responsible for sensation and motor control of the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso, loss of this blood supply results in paralysis and loss of sensation in the contralateral head, upper extremity and torso.

item.label: Lateral ventricle
item.name: Lateral ventricle
item.description: The lateral ventricle is a large, C-shaped space within each cerebral hemisphere that is filled with cerebrospinal fluid. It consists of an anterior (or frontal) horn that extends into the frontal lobe, a body, a posterior (or occipital) horn that extends into the occipital lobe, an inferior (or temporal) horn that extends into the temporal lobe and the atrium or trigone where the body, posterior limb and inferior limb meet.

item.label: Third ventricle
item.name: Third ventricle
item.description: The third ventricle is a single, narrow, vertically-oriented portion of the ventricular system.  It is located between the two halves of the thalamus and hypothalamus.

item.label: Cerebral aqueduct
item.name: Cerebral aqueduct
item.description: The cerebral aqueduct is AKA the cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius.  It is a narrow channel within the midbrain through which cerebrospinal fluid flows from the third ventricle into the fourth ventricle.
